bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, September 5, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes about his hiking and Amsterdam. He is looking forward to resting on the steamer and seeing her again.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, September 5, 1890
div1.p:
I am now in the freight
office at Amsterdam waiting to go
through some miserable formality about
the stuff I sent down from Heidelberg.
We arrived here last night by
rail from Cologne and this morning
I went at once to the bank where
I received two letters from you
which I enjoyed very much. I am
afraid another will come tonight
or to-morrow and that I will
miss it. I will go to the bank
again today. Did I forget to tell
you about the trip over the
channel? Well, there was not
a motion of the boat. The channel
was like a river.

I am delighted to hear that you
have won the second round
in the wild case. It must come
all right in the end.

Our walk since I last wrote
has been uneventful. The scenery
all the time was very fine.
We stayed a night at
St. Goarshousen near the
Lorlei where I think I
wrote to you. The next night
we stayed at Eugers. (Come
to think of it, it was at
Eugers that I wrote to you.)
The next night was at
Konigswinter making
a walk of over a hundred
miles in three days.

We walked up to Bonn
on Wednesday morning
I looked over that town
and then rode to Cologne
From We stayed at Cologne
until yesterday afternoon
and then came on here.
Cologne is a very interesting
place. The cathedral is
grand.

Amsterdam is a very
curious place. Full
of canals and bridges.
The language is very odd.
it is somewhat like the
German but it has a
decided resemblance
to the English. It is
sometimes really laughable.

We have now attended
to all our luggage, and
nothing remains now but
to go on board. The vessel
sails at 8 tomorrow
morning, so we will go
on board tonight.

She is a very decent looking
boat about the size of
the “Ethiopia.” When I reach
New York I will go
right to Mrs. Denison's, and
I will telegraph to
you as soon as we
arrive. We will not
reach New York before the
20th. You can write
to me c/o Mrs. Denison and
please say if you are
going to Baltimore to
look over the boxes. I will
go then if you will,
or I will go there by
myself and attend to
them if you would
rather not go. When
I reach New York I
will look up the
boarding-houses, the addresses
of which you gave me.

Now that my trip is over
and I look back on it
all, I can see that I
have gained considerable
information, I also have
cause for regret at not
seeing more of some of
the places, but as it is
the labor was very
great and I am glad
of the two weeks rest
that I must have on the
steamer. A trip such
as I have taken is very
instructive but there is
very little pleasure in it.
Throughout the whole
thing my idea was to
learn not to enjoy.

I am very glad to think
that I have not long to
wait before seeing you.
